question: What is the formal name of the Florence Cathedral?
answer: Florence Cathedral (Italian: Duomo di Firenze), formally the Cathedral of Saint Mary of the Flower (Italian: Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore [katteˈdraːle di ˈsanta maˈriːa del ˈfjoːre]), is the cathedral of the Catholic Archdiocese of Florence.

question: What style is the basilica's exterior primarily composed of?
answer: Commenced in 1296 in the Gothic style to a design of Arnolfo di Cambio and structurally completed by 1436 with the dome engineered by Filippo Brunelleschi; the basilica's exterior is faced with polychrome marble panels in various shades of green and pink, bordered by white, and features an elaborate 19th-century Gothic Revival (west) façade by Emilio De Fabris.

question: Where is the cathedral complex located in Florence?
answer: The cathedral complex, in Piazza del Duomo, includes the Baptistery and Giotto's Campanile, and it is present in the district San Giovanni.

question: What is the name of the UNESCO World Heritage Site mentioned in the text?
answer: These three buildings are part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site covering the historic centre of Florence and are a major tourist attraction of Tuscany.

question: When was the basilica's dome first built?
answer: The basilica is one of Italy's largest churches and its dome, when first built back in the 15th century, was the largest ever built in western Europe.

question: What is the name of the dome that was later overtaken by St Peter's Basilica?
answer: Although it was later overtaken by St Peter's Basilica, it still remains the largest dome ever constructed of bricks.

question: What is the role of the cathedral in the Archdiocese of Florence?
answer: The cathedral is the mother church of the Archdiocese of Florence, whose archbishop is Gherardo Gambelli.

question: When was the first building of the Basilica di San Lorenzo di Firenze consecrated as a church?
answer: Santa Maria del Fiore was built on the site of Florence's second cathedral dedicated to Saint Reparata; the first was the Basilica di San Lorenzo di Firenze, the first building of which was consecrated as a church in 393 by St. Ambrose of Milan.

question: What was the approximate time period when the structure was founded?
answer: The ancient structure, founded in the early 5th century and having undergone many repairs, was crumbling with age, according to the 14th-century Nuova Cronica of Giovanni Villani, and was no longer large enough to serve the growing population of the city.

question: What was the reason for the incomplete reconstruction of Siena's cathedral?
answer: Other major Tuscan cities had undertaken ambitious reconstructions of their cathedrals during the Late Medieval period, such as Pisa and particularly Siena where the enormous proposed extensions were never completed.

question: What was the year the city council approved Arnolfo di Cambio's design for the new church?
answer: The city council approved Arnolfo di Cambio's design for the new church in 1294.

question: Who is Di Cambio?
answer: Di Cambio was also architect of the church of Santa Croce and the Palazzo Vecchio.

question: What architectural feature is covered by the middle nave?
answer: He designed three wide naves ending under the octagonal dome, with the middle nave covering the area of Santa Reparata.

question: What was the date that the first stone was laid?
answer: The first stone was laid on 9 September 1296, by Cardinal Valeriana, the first papal legate ever sent to Florence.

question: What was the original planned duration of the building of this vast project?
answer: The building of this vast project was to last 140 years; Arnolfo's plan for the eastern end, although maintained in concept, was greatly expanded in size.

question: Who was Arnolfo?
answer: After Arnolfo died in 1302, work on the cathedral slowed for almost 50 years.

question: What was the significance of the discovery of the relics of Saint Zenobius in 1330?
answer: When the relics of Saint Zenobius were discovered in 1330 in Santa Reparata, the project gained a new impetus.

question: Who was appointed by the Arte della Lana to oversee the construction of the cathedral in 1334?
answer: In 1331, the Arte della Lana, the guild of wool merchants, took over patronage for the construction of the cathedral and in 1334 appointed Giotto to oversee the work.

question: Who designed the original plan for the Florence Cathedral before Giotto continued the work?
answer: Assisted by Andrea Pisano, Giotto continued di Cambio's design.

question: Who built the campanile?
answer: His major accomplishment was the building of the campanile.

question: Who was halted due to the Black Death in 1348?
answer: When Giotto died on 8 January 1337, Andrea Pisano continued the building until work was halted due to the Black Death in 1348.

question: What style of art is the fresco by Andrea di Bonaiuto?
answer: The Duomo, as if completed, in a fresco by Andrea di Bonaiuto, painted in the 1360s, before the commencement of the dome.

question: Who was the first architect to resume work on the cathedral in 1349?
answer: In 1349, action resumed on the cathedral under a series of architects, starting with Francesco Talenti, who finished the campanile and enlarged the overall project to include the apse and the side chapels.

question: Who succeeded Giovanni di Lapo Ghini as the master of the building project.
answer: In 1359, Talenti was succeeded by Giovanni di Lapo Ghini (1360–1369) who divided the centre nave in four square bays.

question: Who is Neri di Fioravanti?
answer: Other architects were Alberto Arnoldi, Giovanni d'Ambrogio, Neri di Fioravanti, and Andrea Orcagna.

question: What was the purpose of demolishing the old church Santa Reparata?
answer: By 1375, the old church Santa Reparata was pulled down.

question: What structure was being worked on during this time period?
answer: The nave was finished by 1380, and only the dome remained incomplete until 1436.

question: What was the name of the organization that announced the architectural design competition for erecting Neri's dome?
answer: On 19 August 1418, the Arte della Lana announced an architectural design competition for erecting Neri's dome.

question: Who supported Filippo Brunelleschi in the competition?
answer: The two main competitors were two master goldsmiths, Lorenzo Ghiberti and Filippo Brunelleschi, the latter of whom was supported by Cosimo de Medici.

question: Who was Ghiberti's lifelong competitor mentioned in the text?
answer: Ghiberti had been the winner of a competition for a pair of bronze doors for the Baptistery in 1401, and lifelong competition between the two remained sharp.

question: Who did Brunelleschi beat to win the commission?
answer: Brunelleschi won and received the commission.

question: Did Brunelleschi receive the announced prize of 200 florins?
answer: Ghiberti, appointed coadjutor, drew a salary equal to Brunelleschi's and, though neither was awarded the announced prize of 200 florins, was promised equal credit, although he spent most of his time on other projects.

question: Who took over the project when Brunelleschi became ill?
answer: When Brunelleschi became ill, or feigned illness, the project was briefly in the hands of Ghiberti.

question: How did Ghiberti's perception of the project change over time?
answer: But Ghiberti soon had to admit that the whole project was beyond him.

question: What event led to Brunelleschi being in charge again in 1423?
answer: In 1423, Brunelleschi was back in charge and took over sole responsibility.

question: What architectural structure was being erected during this time period?
answer: Erection of the dome had begun in 1420 and was finished in 1436.

question: What day of the year was the cathedral consecrated according to the Florentine calendar?
answer: The cathedral was consecrated by Pope Eugene IV on 25 March 1436, the first day of the year according to the Florentine calendar.

question: What was the significance of the dome's construction method in history?
answer: It was the first 'octagonal' dome in history to be built without a temporary wooden supporting frame.

question: When was Guillaume Dufay's motet Nuper rosarum flores written?
answer: During the consecration in 1436, Guillaume Dufay's motet Nuper rosarum flores was performed.

question: Who initiated a design competition for the façade of the cathedral in 1490-1491?
answer: The decoration of the exterior of the cathedral, begun in the 14th century, was left unfinished after the initial works done by Arnolfo di Cambio, which led Lorenzo de' Medici to initiate a design competition for the façade between 1490 and 1491.

question: When was the polychrome marble façade of the building completed?
answer: The competition went ultimately nowhere, and the façade was not completed until 1887, when the polychrome marble façade was completed with the design of Emilio De Fabris.

question: When was the floor of the church originally laid?
answer: The floor of the church was relaid in marble tiles in the 16th century.

question: What type of marble is primarily white?
answer: The exterior walls are faced in alternate vertical and horizontal bands of polychrome marble from Carrara (white), Prato (green), Siena (red), Lavenza and a few other places.

question: What architectural style are the Battistero di San Giovanni and Giotto's Bell Tower primarily associated with?
answer: These marble bands had to repeat the already existing bands on the walls of the earlier adjacent baptistery, the Battistero di San Giovanni, and Giotto's Bell Tower.

question: Who created the sculptures at the Door of the Mandorla?
answer: There are two side doors: the Doors of the Canonici (south side) and the Door of the Mandorla (north side) with sculptures by Nanni di Banco, Donatello, and Jacopo della Quercia.

question: What architectural style is often associated with delicate tracery and ornaments?
answer: The six side windows, notable for their delicate tracery and ornaments, are separated by pilasters.

question: What is the purpose of the two windows that are described as merely ornamental?
answer: Only the four windows closest to the transept admit light; the other two are merely ornamental.

question: What architectural style is being described in the text?
answer: The clerestory windows are round, a common feature in Italian Gothic.

question: What is the purpose of the system?
